channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Strava Fitness App Can Reveal Military Sites, Analysts Say
item.media:description: A “heat map,” showing the movements of people who have made their activity public.
item.description: A global map published by the company shows users’ movements and is said to expose data about bases and personnel, including those of U.S. forces in Iraq and Syria.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA and MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: As Afghan Attacks Intensify, So Does Anger at Country’s Leaders
item.media:description: Security by the site of an attack near a military academy in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Monday.
item.description: With insurgent attacks killing more than 130 people in 10 days, Afghans are asking why the government cannot protect its heavily militarized capital.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and FAHIM ABED
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Tired of Their Veils, Some Iranian Women Stage Rare Protests
item.media:description: Inspired perhaps by a “White Wednesday” campaign, several Iranian women have publicly taken off their head scarves and waved them on the end of a stick. Six did so on Monday.
item.description: Following the lead of a woman’s protest in late December, six women in Tehran took off their head scarves in public Monday and waved them overhead on a stick.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: The Hague Journal: When Animals Are at Risk, Special Netherlands Police Force Defends Them
item.media:description: Sgt. Erik Smit, left, and a firefighter rescued a dog from a balcony where it had been left alone in snowy conditions in The Hague.
item.media:credit: Jasper Juinen for The New York Times
item.description: Like a Humane Society with guns, handcuffs and badges, the animal police force provides a mixture of animal protection and human social services.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE

item.title: In Canada, a ‘Perfect Storm’ for a #MeToo Reckoning
item.media:description: Employment, Workforce Development and Labour Minister Patricia Hajdu speaks in the House of Commons about Bill-65 on Parliament Hill in Ottawa on Monday.
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: Canada’s House of Commons will debate workplace law changes to define sexual harassment and protect political staff members.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: North Korea Cancels Pre-Olympic Event, Blaming South Korean Media
item.media:description: North Korean women’s ice hockey players arrived last week at South Korea’s national training center in Jincheon.
item.description: North Korea called off a joint cultural performance amid South Koreans’ lukewarm welcome of its Olympic participation.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: As Brexit Agonies Continue, Theresa May Is Under Threat Again
item.media:description: Theresa May, the British prime minister, and Tim Barrow, Britain’s permanent representative to the European Union, arriving at a leaders summit meeting of the bloc in Brussels last month.
item.description: Brexit right-wingers fret about “Brino” — a Brexit in name only. Pro-Europeans are restive, too. And others say Theresa May just has not got a grip.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Powerful Ally of Xi Jinping Makes Political Comeback in China
item.media:description: Wang Qishan, a close ally of Chinese President Xi Jinping, in Beijing in 2017. He retired from top Communist Party posts last year.
item.description: Wang Qishan, who served as Mr. Xi’s anticorruption chief, retired last year. Does his appointment to the national legislature portend a return to high office?
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Romania Names 3rd Prime Minister in a Year Amid Struggle Over Corruption
item.media:description: Viorica Dancila, on the left of the front row, in Parliament in Bucharest on Monday. Previously little known to many Romanians, she has become the country’s first female prime minister.
item.description: Viorica Dancila, a little-known politician, became the first woman to hold the post.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET

item.title: Toronto Landscaper Killed at Least 5 Men, Police Say
item.media:description: Toronto investigators this month outside a house in Madoc, Ontario, that was part of their inquiry into the killings of at least five men.
item.media:credit: Lars Hagberg/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: The police said Bruce McArthur, 66, hid the remains of some of his victims in planters where he worked. Several victims had ties to a predominantly gay neighborhood.
item.dc:creator: NIRAJ CHOKSHI

item.title: Vatican Asks 2 Bishops in China to Cede Posts to Beijing’s Picks
item.media:description: Easter service at the government-sanctioned West Beijing Catholic Church. About half of the 10 to 12 million Catholics in China worship in underground churches.
item.description: The decision is part of an extraordinary effort by the Vatican to restore ties with China after a nearly 70-year schism among Catholics in the country.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: 3 Philippine Officers Charged in a Killing That Spurred Outrage
item.media:description: The funeral of Kian Loyd delos Santos in Manila in August. His death ignited public anger at President Rodrigo Duterte’s antidrug campaign.
item.description: The officers were charged in connection with the killing of Kian Loyd delos Santos, 17, which strengthened opposition to the government’s brutal antidrug crackdown.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: A D-Day Plane Lost for Years Is About to Fly Again
item.media:description: This Douglas C-47 led the formation carrying American paratroopers to the D-Day invasion. It is being restored in hopes it will fly over Normandy on the 75th anniversary of the invasion in June 2019.
item.description: A twin-engine C-47 called “That’s All, Brother” that led Allied aircraft into France on D-Day sat for years at a bone yard in Wisconsin. It could soon fly over Normandy again.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Fire Breaks Out at Taiwan Refinery
item.description: The blaze in Taoyuan, home to the international airport, went on for hours, and the city fined the company that owns the facility for contributing to air pollution.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Kiribati Ferry Search Expands After 7 Are Found Alive
item.media:description: A dinghy, left, was found in the Pacific carrying seven survivors from a missing ferry; they were taken to the fishing boat at right.
item.media:credit: New Zealand Defence Force, via Associated Press
item.description: The survivors were found “in the baking sun” after more than a week without supplies, shade or a motor for their dinghy.
item.dc:creator: CHARLOTTE GRAHAM

item.title: Explorer: A Journey Into Iraqi Kurdistan
item.media:description: An ancient city gate in Amadiya, in the Kurdish region of Iraq.
item.description: Ancient fortresses, crisp mountain streams, curious people and healing cities: Travelers are discovering the Kurdish Region of Iraq, a place of great beauty, haunted by war.
item.dc:creator: TIM NEVILLE

item.title: Trump Tells British TV He Would Take ‘Tougher’ Stance on Brexit
item.media:description: President Trump arriving at the White House on Friday after returning from the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. Mr. Trump gave an interview to the British journalist Piers Morgan in Davos.
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.description: In an interview with a British broadcaster, President Trump also expressed annoyance with European Union trade policy and said he was looking forward to visiting Britain.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Attack Near Kabul Military Academy Kills 11 Afghan Soldiers
item.media:description: Afghan security personnel at the site of an attack outside Marshal Fahim University in Kabul on Monday.
item.description: Suicide bombers targeted an army unit beside the main Afghan military university, adding to the toll of a violent stretch in the Afghan capital.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and FAHIM ABED

item.title: Chinese Investors Keep Losing Billions Online. Here’s Why.
item.media:description: Zhang Xiaolei, the founder of Qianbao, an online Chinese investment platform, appeared on state-run television after he turned himself in.
item.description: The country’s latest $5 billion flameout shows how smartphones and the rise of online finance lure unsophisticated investors hoping for high returns.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: The Interpreter: Why Attack Afghan Civilians? Creating Chaos Rewards Taliban
item.media:description: The scene of a bomb blast in central Kabul, Afghanistan, on Saturday.
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.description: The central issue in the 16-year war has become whether Afghanistan can have a functioning state. The Taliban have every incentive to expose government weakness.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Olympic Dreams of a United Korea? Many in South Say, ‘No, Thanks’
item.media:description: A fence near the Demilitarized Zone dividing North and South Korea, covered with ribbons calling for peace and reunification. In the South, a united Korea is no longer a sacrosanct goal.
item.description: Young Koreans are more focused on domestic issues, like unemployment and whether they can live as well as their parents did, than a costly and complex reunification.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Finland’s President Elected to 2nd Term, Avoiding a Runoff
item.media:description: President Sauli Niinisto, center, with party members and supporters in Helsinki on Sunday as the results of the election came in.
item.description: Sauli Niinisto, who captured over 60 percent of the vote, has laid out a cautious vision for his next term.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD MARTYN-HEMPHILL

item.title: Female Kurdish Fighter Kills Turkish Troops in Likely Suicide Bombing in Syria
item.media:description: The Turkish military offensive against Kurdish militias in the Afrin area of northern Syria has put Turkey and the United States in the awkward position of fighting with and against the same ally.
item.description: The Kurdish bomber, 20, fought for a part of the Syrian Democratic Forces, an important ally of the United States military in the battle against the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Iran Grants Baquer Namazi, 81, Four-Day Release From Evin Prison
item.media:description: Jared Genser, left, a lawyer, with Babak Namazi, a son of Baquer Namazi, in Vienna last year. The elder Mr. Namazi and another son, Siamak Namazi (in background photos) were convicted of collaborating with the United States.
item.description: A lawyer for Mr. Namazi, the oldest American known to be imprisoned in Iran, said he had been released temporarily because of poor health.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Colombia Police Station Bombings Kill 7 Officers
item.media:description: Police officers standing guard on Sunday near the site of a bomb attack at a police station in Barranquilla, Colombia.
item.description: The three bombings, carried out within 24 hours of one another, reminded Colombians of the attacks against police ordered by Pablo Escobar decades ago.
item.dc:creator: JOE PARKIN DANIELS

item.title: France Rethinks Honor for Charles Maurras, Condemned as Anti-Semite
item.media:description: After public outrage, France’s culture minister, Françoise Nyssen, ordered a revision of the 2018 edition of the National Commemorations to erase any mention of Charles Maurras.
item.description: The presence of the influential writer in a book commemorating notable anniversaries has highlighted France’s ambivalent views toward its history.
item.dc:creator: ELIAN PELTIER

item.title: Tech Giants Brace for Europe’s New Data Privacy Rules
item.media:description: Facebook’s London office. The social network has not rolled out certain products in Europe because they may violate the region’s privacy laws.
item.description: A stringent set of data protection rules will take effect in Europe in May. Facebook, Google and others are working overtime to be ready.
item.dc:creator: SHEERA FRENKEL

item.title: Sara Netanyahu’s Aides Sued Over Her Tirades. Now, There’s a Recording.
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and his wife, Sara, in Jerusalem last year.
item.description: The Israeli premier’s embattled wife can be heard screaming at a publicist over a gossip item that did not mention her college and graduate degrees.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Beijing Journal: The Propaganda I See on My Morning Commute
item.media:description: In Sanlitun Soho, a commercial and office complex in Beijing, a giant electronic billboard displays this message from the Chinese Communist Party: “The people have faith. The nation has hope. The state has strength.”
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.description: In Beijing, socialist slogans butt up against ads for luxury cars and hair transplants, part of the Communist Party’s efforts to inspire loyalty.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Oil Boom Gives the U.S. a New Edge in Energy and Diplomacy
item.media:description: A pump jack in a Permian Basin oil field in West Texas. The area has been a focus of the shale drilling boom.
item.description: Having survived a slump, shale drilling is surging as prices recover, limiting market upheaval and providing Washington with strategic leeway.
item.dc:creator: CLIFFORD KRAUSS
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

item.title: Iranians Prayed for Rain, but Were Covered in Snow
item.media:description: In recent years, Tehran has mainly been covered in yellow smog during the winter months, but it was blanketed in snow on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.description: The country has been gripped by a terrible drought, so a blizzard brought joy — although the relief was most likely only temporary.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Climber Rescued on Pakistan’s ‘Killer Mountain,’ but Another Is in Peril
item.media:description: The Polish climber Tomek Mackiewicz on Nanga Parbat in Pakistan in 2014.
item.description: An elite team came to the rescue of the French climber Elisabeth Revol, but extremely harsh conditions made it impossible to reach her Polish partner, Tomek Mackiewicz.
item.dc:creator: MEHER AHMAD

item.title: Russians Brave Icy Temperatures to Protest Putin and Election
item.media:description: Protesters on Sunday in Moscow, where rallies called by the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny were banned. “You have your own life at stake,” Mr. Navalny said in a recorded message.
item.description: Demonstrators turned out across the country against what they called a lack of choice in the March 2018 presidential vote, which is almost certain to give President Vladimir Putin a fourth term.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR and IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: At Davos, the Real Star May Have Been China, Not Trump
item.media:description: Liu He, a top economic policy adviser to President Xi Jinping of China, drew a full house to his presentation during a meeting of global business and political leaders in Davos, Switzerland.
item.description: While President Trump reassured business leaders that he wanted trade to continue, Beijing extended its economic reach to Latin America and the Arctic.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Bolivia Tells President His Time Is Up. He Isn’t Listening.
item.media:description: President Evo Morales of Bolivia, center, accompanied by deputies, heads to Congress in the capital, La Paz, to deliver his annual message to the nation on Jan. 22, marking his 12th year in power.
item.description: Voters told President Evo Morales in a referendum it was time to retire. But he intends to run again, part of a tilt toward authoritarian tendencies among both the left and right in Latin America.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Pakistan Army ‘Has Greatly Increased Its Clout’ Under New Chief
item.media:description: Gen. Qamar Javed Bajwa, the chief of the Pakistan army, has stressed that he will not seek the resumption of security aid from the United States, which was suspended by the Trump administration.
item.description: Since assuming what may be the most powerful position in Pakistan, Gen. Qamar Javed Bajwa has left no doubt about who is in charge, even as he deals with a freeze in aid from the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Israel Slams ‘Baseless’ Holocaust Legislation in Poland
item.media:description: Israel’s ambassador to Poland, Anna Azari, at a ceremony on Saturday commemorating the liberation of Auschwitz-Birkenau. The two countries are at odds over a bill in Poland.
item.description: Legislation in Poland that would outlaw blaming Poles for the crimes of the Holocaust drew condemnation from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Israeli lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Ireland Prime Minister Says He Will Campaign to Repeal Abortion Ban
item.media:description: The Irish leader Leo Varadkar said that his beliefs had evolved since 2014, when he described himself as “pro-life.”
item.description: After weeks of uncertainty, Irish prime minister Leo Varadkar confirmed during a Saturday interview that he will campaign in favor of ending his country’s constitutional ban on abortion.
item.dc:creator: ED O’LOUGHLIN

item.title: Canadians Greet Bombardier Decision With Pride and a Little Snark
item.media:description: The Bombardier aerospace company, with a plant in Montreal, Quebec, has become a global symbol of Canadian engineering prowess.
item.description: In Quebec, where aerospace company Bombardier is an inextricable part of economic and cultural identity, Canadians declare victory.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Amid Protests, Honduran President Is Sworn In for 2nd Term
item.media:description: The police in Tegucigalpa used tear gas on Saturday to disperse people protesting the inauguration of Juan Orlando Hernández.
item.description: The pomp-filled ceremony, coming after weeks of unrest over a widely disputed election, was marred by new clashes between security forces and protesters.
item.dc:creator: JEFF ERNST and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: A Deadly Blast in Kabul
item.description: A bomb placed inside an ambulance exploded on a busy Kabul street on Saturday, killing at least 95 people and injuring at least 158 others. The explosion comes a week after another attack shook the city.

item.title: Foreign Fighters Back Kurdish Militia in Syria in Fight Against Turkey
item.media:description: An image from a video released on Friday is said to show foreign fighters in the Kurdish People’s Protection Units militia, also known as the Y.P.G., arriving in Afrin, Syria.
item.description: Many Westerners who identify with the promise of a Kurdish state have joined the Y.P.G. militia, battling first the Islamic State and now Turkey.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Fake Country Carved From Catalonia Means to Mock Separatism
item.media:description: As the new Catalan Parliament met this month in Barcelona, many in a crowd outside held banners reading “libertat,” the Catalan word for “freedom.”
item.description: The founders of make-believe Tabàrnia intend for it to send a serious message: That one declaration of independence could set off a cascading series of breakaway nations, to the point of absurdity.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Finland’s Scene-Stealing First Dog Is Missed During Dull Election
item.media:description: President Sauli Niinisto of Finland, with his wife, Jenni Haukio, and their dog, Lennu.
item.description: Lennu, a much-loved celebrity in Finland, is a Boston terrier with a lolling tongue whose master, the president, is up for re-election. But an illness has apparently kept Lennu off the campaign trail.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD MARTYN-HEMPHILL

item.title: Czech Republic Re-elects Milos Zeman, Populist Leader and Foe of Migrants
item.media:description: President Milos Zeman in Prague in January. His often-caustic brand of populism has stoked resentment toward Muslim immigrants.
item.description: In rejecting the president’s opponent, the country was poised to continue the same euroskeptic shift as Hungary, Poland and Slovakia.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA

item.title: Ambush on Mali Army Camp Leaves 14 Soldiers and 17 Attackers Dead
item.description: Islamic militants stormed the camp in the Timbuktu region, but the military struck back and killed many extremists, an army spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Billionaire Saudi Prince, Alwaleed bin Talal, Is Freed From Detention
item.description: Saudi Arabia’s most prominent investor, he had been detained in the Ritz-Carlton in the capital after a mass crackdown on corruption.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
